questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with persistent hypertension. Laboratory evaluation shows elevated aldosterone levels with suppressed renin activity. Which of the following findings is not seen? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sodium loss

 

Explanation:

 

Primary hyperaldosteronism presents with hypertension and elevated aldosterone levels with suppressed renin activity. Key features:

 

  • Increased sodium reabsorption ‚Üí Sodium retention (NOT loss)
  • Increased potassium excretion ‚Üí Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis ‚Üí Due to increased hydrogen ion excretion
  • Muscle cramps ‚Üí Due to hypokalemia and electrolyte imbalance

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypokalemia: Incorrect, as it is a classic finding in primary hyperaldosteronism due to increased urinary potassium excretion

 

Option C. Metabolic alkalosis: Incorrect, as it occurs due to hydrogen ion loss and potassium depletion

 

Option D. Muscle cramps: Incorrect, as they are commonly seen in primary hyperaldosteronism, primarily due to hypokalemia

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary hyperaldosteronism causes sodium retention (not sodium loss) and presents with hypertension, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and muscle cramps.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented to the hospital with palpitations. Physical examination showed a diastolic murmur in the left 3rd intercostal space. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Aortic regurgitation

 

The presence of a diastolic murmur heard best at the left 3rd intercostal space (Erb's point) is characteristic of aortic regurgitation. Aortic regurgitation occurs when the aortic valve does not close properly, allowing blood to flow back into the left ventricle during diastole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic stenosis: This condition produces a systolic ejection murmur, typically heard at the right second intercostal space.

 

Option C. Mitral regurgitation: This condition causes a pansystolic murmur heard best at the apex of the heart and radiates to the axilla.

 

Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation: This condition causes a pansystolic murmur heard best at the lower left sternal border.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic Regurgitation is associated with a diastolic murmur, best heard at Erb’s point (left 3rd intercostal space). The murmur is typically described as a high-pitched, blowing, decrescendo murmur.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with dyslipidemia has persistently elevated triglyceride levels (600 mg/dL) despite treatment with rosuvastatin. What will be the next step? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gemfibrozil

 

In cases where a patient has dyslipidemia with persistently elevated triglyceride levels, particularly above 500 mg/dL, there is a significant risk of developing pancreatitis. The primary goal in such situations is to lower the triglyceride levels to mitigate this risk. Fibrates, such as gemfibrozil or fenofibrate, are the treatment of choice for reducing triglyceride levels effectively. They act by decreasing the hepatic secretion of very-low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) and increasing the clearance of triglycerides from the blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe is used to reduce low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol levels. It works by inhibiting the absorption of cholesterol in the small intestine. While it is effective for lowering LDL, it is not the first-line treatment for elevated triglycerides.

 

Option B. Niacin: Niacin, or vitamin B3, was previously used to lower both LDL and triglyceride levels. However, it is no longer commonly used in practice due to its side effects and lack of significant additional benefit over other treatments.

 

Option D. Cholestyramine: Cholestyramine is a bile acid sequestrant that is primarily used to lower LDL cholesterol. It is not particularly effective in reducing triglyceride levels and can cause gastrointestinal side effects, making it a less favorable option for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with triglyceride levels above 500 mg/dL, fibrates such as gemfibrozil are the preferred treatment to reduce the risk of pancreatitis.

questions.text: A scuba diver surfaces rapidly, soon experiencing joint pain, dizziness, and difficulty breathing indicating decompression sickness. Which of the following is not associated with it? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Haemodilution

 

Decompression sickness (DCS), or Caisson disease, occurs due to rapid ascent during diving, based on Henry's law. When pressure decreases rapidly, dissolved gases (particularly nitrogen) form bubbles in blood and tissues. These bubbles can cause vascular occlusions, organ damage, and various systemic manifestations including hemoconcentration‚Äînot haemodilution.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coagulopathy: Incorrect. Coagulopathy can occur in DCS due to endothelial damage from gas bubbles, causing a DIC-like picture in 2‚Äì3% of cases.

 

Option B. Hearing loss: Incorrect. Hearing loss, though rare, is a possible manifestation of DCS due to inner ear involvement.

 

Option D. Visual loss: Incorrect. Visual disturbances and loss can occur in DCS due to bubble formation affecting the visual pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decompression sickness leads to hemoconcentration (not haemodilution) and can present with joint pain ("the bends"), neurological symptoms, coagulopathy, and sensory organ dysfunction including vision and hearing loss.
